questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of lower abdominal pain and pain with urination. Five months ago, she was treated for gonococcal urethritis. She recently moved in with her newlywed husband. She is sexually active with her husband and they do not use condoms. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.7°F) and blood pressure is 120/74 mm Hg. There is tenderness to palpation over the pelvic region. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vulva and vagina. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
8400/mm3



Urine



 pH
6.7 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


 Protein
trace


 WBC

60/hpf


 Nitrites

positive


 Bacteria

positive


Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae may lead to sexually transmitted genitourinary tract infections such as urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease, all of which can manifest with dysuria and lower abdominal pain. However, infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically manifests with leukocytosis, purulent vaginal or urethral discharge, and dyspareunia. This patient's symptoms are more consistent with cystitis, which is caused by a different organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is part of the normal flora of the female genital tract and a common cause of cystitis. However, in sexually active young women, S. saprophyticus is only the second most common causal organism of community-acquired cystitis. Moreover, urinary nitrites are typically negative in cases of staphylococcal UTI because staphylococci do not convert nitrate to nitrite.

C) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae is part of the natural flora of the gastrointestinal tract. The capsular polysaccharides of K. pneumoniae are its virulence factor. K. pneumoniae may cause nosocomial infections (e.g., pneumoniae) as well as non-nosocomial urinary tract infections. However, K. pneumoniae is not the most common causative agent of UTIs in sexually active young women.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is part of the normal flora of the colon and only rarely causes UTIs. Therefore, infection with E. faecalis is unlikely in this patient. Also, if this patient did have enterococcal UTI, urinary nitrites would be negative because enterococci do not convert nitrate to nitrite.

E) INCORRECT:

Proteus mirabilis is part of the natural flora of the gastrointestinal tract and can occasionally cause UTIs. Its most significant virulence factor is urease, which causes alkaline urine with an ammonia smell. However, P. mirabilis is not the most common cause of UTI in young women.

F) CORRECT:

Cystitis is usually caused by ascending bacterial infection from the urethra and E. coli is the most common causative organism overall, causing ∼ 80% of cases of urinary tract infections (UTI). Women are anatomically predisposed to cystitis because their urethra is shorter and the anal and genital regions are in close proximity, making it more likely that bacteria might spread from the anal region and colonize the vagina. Sexual intercourse is an important risk factor for contracting UTI, hence the term honeymoon cystitis.

The first-line treatment for acute uncomplicated cystitis in nonpregnant women is trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX). Alternative first-line treatments include nitrofurantoin and fosfomycin.

G) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of sexually transmitted genitourinary infections in the US such as urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, it does not cause cystitis.
questions.hint: This patient's dysuria and tenderness to palpation over the pelvic region alongside elevated WBCs, positive nitrites, and bacteriuria on urinalysis are consistent with a urinary tract infection (UTI) and highly suggestive of cystitis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of abdominal pain and frequent urination. Her mother reports that her daughter wet the bed the previous night and that the urine smelled bad. She was toilet-trained for 4 months and has had very few accidents since then. She takes frequent bubble baths. Her last bowel movement was 3 days ago. She was born at term after a normal gestation and has reached all developmental milestones. She has had two upper respiratory infections within the last 6 months that resolved without treatment. Her 12-year-old brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the abdomen shows mild suprapubic tenderness. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase, nitrite, and blood; urinalysis shows white blood cells and gram-negative rods. Which of the following risk factors most likely contributed to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bubble baths can contribute to the development of vulvovaginitis in prepubertal children. Due to low estrogen levels, vulvar skin and vaginal mucosa are thin and susceptible to irritants (e.g., bubble baths, perfumed soaps), which disrupt the natural acidic pH balance and predispose to inflammation and infection. While vulvovaginitis can manifest with increased urinary frequency and pain in the lower abdomen and/or suprapubic region, it usually causes pruritus, redness and/or a burning sensation. Bubble baths are not a risk factor for UTIs.

B) CORRECT:

Constipation is a known risk factor for UTIs in children. Prolonged fecal retention leads to bladder dysfunction and urinary stasis, which in turn promotes bacterial overgrowth. This child has not had a bowel movement in 3 days, which has likely contributed to her UTI. Causes of constipation in children include social stressors (e.g., family conflicts and school pressures), low fiber diet, dehydration, lack of physical activity, and underlying conditions (e.g., Hirschsprung disease, hypothyroidism, and cystic fibrosis). Constipation is especially common in children who have recently started toilet training (e.g., withholding maneuvers because of unavailability of toilets).

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns and are often identified in utero via ultrasound. Although congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract are a risk factor for recurrent pediatric UTIs, PUVs are found almost exclusively in boys and typically cause symptoms early in infancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory tract infection (RTI) can lead to UTI if the causative pathogen is transmitted to the urinary tract. This is more common in recently toilet-trained children because they often have poor genital and hand hygiene, which makes transmission of microorganisms from mouth to genitals more likely. Although this patient has a history of recent RTIs, the gram-negative rods found on urinalysis are unlikely to be due to an RTI. A different risk factor is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with diabetes mellitus are predisposed to UTI because abundant glucose in the urine acts as a nutrient source and encourages bacterial overgrowth. Moreover, this condition can cause varying degrees of immune dysfunction, which further predisposes patients to infection. Although this patient has a family history of diabetes mellitus, she does not have common features of the condition, such as weight loss, polydipsia, polyuria, or glucosuria.
questions.hint: This toilet-trained child presents with suprapubic tenderness, urinary frequency, strong-smelling urine, and urinary incontinence, raising suspicion for urinary tract infection (UTI). Abnormal findings on urine dipstick (e.g., nitrite) and urinalysis (e.g., bacteriuria) confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from her nursing home because of increasing confusion and lethargy for 12 hours. The nursing home aide says she did not want to get out of bed this morning and seemed less responsive than usual. She has Alzheimer disease, hypertension, and a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis for which she underwent percutaneous nephrolithotomy repeatedly. She has chronic, intractable urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. Current medications include galantamine, memantine, and ramipril. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation of the lower abdomen. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9000/mm3



Platelet count
355,000/mm3



Urine



 pH


8.5 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


 Glucose
1+


 Protein
2+


 Ketones
negative


 RBC
5/hpf


 WBC

35/hpf


 Bacteria

moderate


 Nitrites

positive


Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of UTI overall, as well as the most common cause of catheter-associated UTI. While urinalysis in UTI due to E. coli typically shows positive nitrite, E. coli does not cause alkaline urine. In addition, it is not commonly associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with a UTI, alkaline urine (pH > 8), and an indwelling urinary catheter are most likely infected with Proteus mirabilis. P. mirabilis converts urea in the urine into ammonia, which has an alkalizing effect and can cause magnesium ammonium phosphate stones (i.e., struvite kidney stones), which typically require interventional stone removal. The incidence of P. mirabilis increases with the duration of catheterization; it is rare in short-term catheterization but has been found in ∼ 40% of chronically catheterized patients. In this case, empiric antibiotic treatment with parenteral ceftriaxone or ciprofloxacin, urine culture and sensitivity testing, replacement of the urinary catheter (due to risk of colonization and biofilm formation), and (if confirmed) stone removal are the most appropriate next steps in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor recurrent nephrolithiasis. Furthermore, because enterococci are unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in case of enterococcal UTI.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI, especially because of its ability to form biofilms that are resistant to antibiotic therapy. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor does it commonly lead to recurrent nephrolithiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common cause of UTI in young, sexually active women. It is rare in older and/or catheterized patients. Although S. saprophyticus produces urease and thereby alkalinizes urine, it is unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite. Therefore, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in cases of staphylococcal UTI.

F) INCORRECT:

Enterobacter cloacae can cause UTI, particularly in women. It is rare in catheterized patients, does not produce an alkaline urine pH, and is not associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory studies are highly suggestive of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The organism most likely responsible produces urease, which can convert urea into ammonia and lend urine a characteristic scent.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 5-month history of worsening bladder discomfort. Her discomfort is relieved by voiding. She voids 10–15 times per day and wakes up 2–3 times per night to void. She has not had any involuntary loss of urine. She has tried cutting down on fluids and taking NSAIDs to reduce the discomfort with minimal relief. Her past medical history is significant for bipolar disorder. She is sexually active with her husband but reports that intercourse has recently become painful. Current medications include lithium. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness to palpation of her suprapubic region. Urinalysis shows:


Color
clear


pH
6.7 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


Specific gravity
1.010 (N = 1.003–1.040)


Protein
1+


Glucose
negative


Ketones
negative


Blood
negative


Nitrite
negative


Leukocyte esterase
negative


WBC
0/hpf


Squamous epithelial cells
2/hpf


Bacteria
None


Pelvic ultrasound shows that postvoid residual urine is 25 mL. A cystoscopy shows a normal urethra and normal bladder mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections commonly cause suprapubic tenderness and increased urinary frequency. However, this patient has a negative urinalysis (no nitrites, bacteria, or leukocyte esterase), suggesting a noninfectious cause for her cystitis. Furthermore, her discomfort is relieved during voiding, unlike the dysuria that is typically associated with an infection of the urinary tract.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia (all symptoms of an overactive bladder). However, she additionally notes suprapubic tenderness and bladder discomfort relieved by voiding, which rarely occurs in patients with overactive bladder. Furthermore, dyspareunia is not typically associated with an overactive bladder.

C) CORRECT:

Interstitial cystitis (IC) is a chronic, noninfectious cause of cystitis with an unknown etiology. Patients with IC often present with suprapubic pain, dyspareunia, and increased urgency/frequency for longer than 6 weeks. IC is a diagnosis of exclusion and other causes of cystitis such as urinary tract infection, sexually transmitted infection, or bladder masses must be ruled out first. Some patients with IC can have ulcerations and submucosal hemorrhages seen on cystoscopic examination, though the presence of these findings is not required for diagnosis. Because urinalysis, cystoscopy, and postvoid residual bladder scan were all normal, IC remains the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with urinary retention can present with suprapubic pain and urinary incontinence. However, this woman had a normal postvoid residual volume (chronic retention usually manifests with > 300 mL residual volume). Additionally, this patient has no risk factors for urinary retention such as recent surgery, anticholinergic medication use, or peripheral neuropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes insipidus, which may be caused by lithium use, is a rare condition that can lead to polyuria and increased urinary urgency. Because this patient also complains of suprapubic discomfort, an inflammatory condition is a more likely cause of her urinary symptoms. Additionally, urine-specific gravity tends to be very low (< 1.003) in patients with diabetes insipidus.
questions.hint: This patient presents with chronic bladder discomfort, increased urinary frequency, suprapubic tenderness, and dyspareunia. Some of her symptoms have been present for 5 months. Of note, her urine dipstick is negative for leukocyte esterase, pyuria, or nitrites.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and severe burning with urination. Two years ago, she was diagnosed with cervical cancer and was successfully treated with a combination of radiation and chemotherapy. She has systemic lupus erythematosus and finished a course of cyclophosphamide 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 12 years. Current medication includes hydroxychloroquine. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the pelvic region. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7400/mm3



Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Urine



 pH
7 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


 WBC

62/hpf


 RBC
12/hpf


 Protein
negative


 Nitrites

positive


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiation-induced inflammation of the mucosa of the bladder is the underlying mechanism of radiation cystitis. This condition is a potential complication of radiotherapy, which was used to treat cervical cancer in this patient. Radiation cystitis can occur several years after radiation therapy and manifests with dysuria and microscopic hematuria, as seen here. However, pyuria and positive nitrites indicate that the patient's symptoms are due to infection rather than radiation-induced tissue damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation of urothelial cells is the most common underlying mechanism of bladder cancer. Although it is exceedingly rare in patients this young, bladder cancer is possible in this woman given the presence of risk factors such as smoking, pelvic irradiation, and cyclophosphamide treatment. However, the most common symptom in patients with bladder carcinoma is painless gross hematuria; pelvic pain and dysuria (which are seen in this patient) would be very late manifestations of bladder cancer. In this case, pyuria and a positive nitrite test suggest an infectious etiology.

C) CORRECT:

The most common cause of UTI is ascending infection. Women have a higher risk of contracting UTIs because they have a shorter urethra, which allows bacteria that colonize the vulva and perineum to ascend into the bladder. Moreover, this woman has several risk factors for UTIs, such as multiple sexual partners and the use of a diaphragm, which alters the vaginal flora and makes users more prone to the introduction of uropathogens to the lower urinary tract. Untreated lower UTIs can ascend the ureters to the kidneys, causing pyelonephritis.

Symptoms of lower urinary tract infection in a nonpregnant woman without a history of periurethral intervention or evidence of anatomical or functional abnormalities suggest uncomplicated cystitis. This patient should be treated with nitrofurantoin for 5 days, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for 3 days, or a single dose of fosfomycin.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower abdominal pain and dysuria can be symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which most often occurs due to a sexually transmitted infection (STI) with Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Pyuria, as seen in this case, may result from any inflammatory process within the pelvis, including PID. Moreover, the fact that this patient has multiple sexual partners and does not use barrier protection puts her at increased risk of contracting an STI. However, the absence of fever, vaginal discharge, or leukocytosis suggests a urinary tract infection rather than PID.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide, which was used to treat a flare of systemic lupus erythematosus in this patient, can cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis (as well as nonhemorrhagic cystitis). Although patients with hemorrhagic cystitis can present with hematuria and dysuria, the presence of pyuria and a positive nitrite test in this patient's urinalysis indicate that her symptoms are due to infection. Furthermore, chemotherapy-induced cystitis typically occurs within hours to days of infusion.

F) INCORRECT:

While hematogenous spread does not play a role in the pathogenesis of uropathogenic cystitis, pyelonephritis may be caused by this mechanism, especially in neonates and IV drug users. However, in addition to abdominal pain, dysuria, pyuria, and microhematuria, pyelonephritis would manifest with high fever/chills, costovertebral angle tenderness, and WBC casts on urinalysis, none of which are present in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Neural hypersensitivity is one of the suspected mechanisms leading to interstitial cystitis. Interstitial cystitis can manifest with dysuria and pelvic pain. If Hunner's ulcers develop, interstitial cystitis may also manifest with microscopic hematuria, as seen here. However, interstitial cystitis is a noninfectious disorder that would not cause pyuria or a positive nitrite test. Moreover, by definition, interstitial cystitis is characterized by symptoms lasting ≥ 6 weeks.
questions.hint: This patient's dysuria, pelvic tenderness, microscopic hematuria, pyuria, and positive nitrite test are suggestive of a lower urinary tract infection (UTI).

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her initial prenatal visit. She feels well. She was treated for genital herpes one year ago and gonorrhea 3 months ago. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli (> 100,000 colony forming units/mL). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Single-dose ceftriaxone and azithromycin is the first-line treatment for gonorrhea, which can be asymptomatic in many cases. However, if an asymptomatic infection is suspected, diagnosis (e.g., nucleic acid amplification testing) would be indicated prior to the initiation of treatment. This combination of antibiotics is not used for the treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin should be avoided in this patient because aminoglycosides are teratogenic and can cause irreversible bilateral deafness in the fetus. While aminoglycosides may be administered in nonpregnant patients as a component of second-line treatment for pyelonephritis with either aminopenicillins and beta-lactamase inhibitors or cephalosporins, they are not generally used in the treatment of cystitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the first-line drug for uncomplicated cystitis in nonpregnant women and a second-line antibiotic for the treatment of urinary tract infections in pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters (except in the last month of pregnancy). However, the drug should be avoided in this patient because trimethoprim is a folate antagonist, which may cause fetal neural tube defects in the first trimester of pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria should always be treated promptly during pregnancy. This patient is at a higher risk of developing pyelonephritis from asymptomatic bacteriuria than a nonpregnant woman because, during pregnancy, the widened ureters and increased glucose levels in the urine facilitate the ascension of organisms to the kidney. Furthermore, if left untreated, there is also an increased risk of prematurity and low birth weight. In nonpregnant patients, asymptomatic bacteriuria does not require treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound can be performed to evaluate for urinary retention and signs of pyelonephritis. This pregnant patient's asymptomatic bacteriuria puts her at increased risk of developing pyelonephritis. However, she does not currently have any features that would suggest upper urinary tract involvement (e.g., flank pain, fever, or chills).

F) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is frequently used to treat complicated urinary tract infections in nonpregnant patients. However, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated during pregnancy. As there are other approved antibiotic agents, ciprofloxacin should be avoided in this pregnant patient.

G) CORRECT:

Amoxicillin/clavulanate is a first-line antibiotic agent for asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases the risk of bacteriuria and recurrent urinary tract infections because of increased pressure on the bladder from the growing uterus, urinary stasis, and immunosuppression. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is recommended for all pregnant women in the first trimester. Asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy should always be treated since it increases the risk of pyelonephritis in the mother, as well as preterm delivery and low birth weight.

Other antibiotic agents used to treat cystitis that are safe during pregnancy include oral cephalosporins (e.g., cefpodoxime, cephalexin), fosfomycin, and nitrofurantoin (during the 2nd and 3rd trimesters). Follow-up urine culture is recommended 1–2 weeks after completion of treatment to ensure eradication of bacteriuria.
questions.hint: This patient has no urinary frequency or dysuria, but her urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite, and her urine culture grows E. coli, all of which indicates asymptomatic bacteriuria.

questions.text: Three days after undergoing an open cholecystectomy, a 76-year-old man is evaluated for confusion and fever. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 1 year ago. He does not drink alcohol. Prior to admission to the hospital, his medications included lisinopril, metformin, and ipratropium. He appears acutely ill and lethargic. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/84 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place and time. Examination shows a 10-cm subcostal incision that appears dry and mildly erythematous; there is tenderness to palpation of the lower abdomen without guarding or rebound. Pulmonary examination shows scattered expiratory wheezing throughout both lung fields and no crackles. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urinary catheter is in place and urine output is normal. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?

choices.text: Wound swab for Gram stain and culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A wound swab for Gram stain and culture is used to diagnose incisional surgical site infection (SSI), which can cause postoperative fever and sepsis. Manifestations of SSI include localized swelling, tenderness, erythema, and purulent discharge from the incision, whereas this patient's surgical wound is dry and only mildly erythematous. Moreover, SSI is uncommon during the first four days after surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia, which can be diagnosed on chest x-ray, is a common cause of early postoperative fever and the most common source of sepsis. However, this patient does not have further features of pneumonia, such as productive cough, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and typical auscultation findings (e.g., decreased breath sounds, crackles). The scattered bilateral wheezing is likely related to his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. While underlying pneumonia cannot be definitively ruled out, it is not the most likely cause of sepsis in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Peritoneal fluid analysis can be used to diagnose biliary leak following cholecystectomy. Biliary leak can manifest with abdominal discomfort and fever, but jaundice, nausea, and vomiting are also typically seen. If secondary bacterial peritonitis develops, patients present with signs and symptoms of sepsis; however, peritoneal signs such as rebound tenderness and/or guarding are also expected. Diagnosis of postoperative biliary leak is usually established with imaging (e.g., CT abdomen, HIDA scan) rather than peritoneal fluid analysis alone. Finally, biliary leak is a typical complication of laparoscopic rather than open cholecystectomy.

D) CORRECT:

Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) are a common cause of postoperative fever and sepsis in patients with indwelling urinary catheters. Symptoms are often nonspecific (e.g., fever, altered mental status, lower abdominal pain), particularly in older patients. Urine culture as well as two sets of blood cultures should ideally be obtained before initiating empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy (e.g., imipenem plus vancomycin) in order to identify the causative organism and determine antibiotic susceptibility. This patient's qSOFA score of 2 (respiratory rate ≥ 22/min and altered mental status) indicates that he is at high risk of in-hospital mortality due to sepsis and should be admitted to the intensive care unit. Complete evaluation for organ dysfunction, continuous cardiac and respiratory monitoring, as well as frequent reassessments of hemodynamic parameters and serial serum lactate, are indicated.

In patients undergoing surgery not involving the urinary tract, urinary catheters should be removed as soon as possible to prevent CAUTIs, preferably within 24 hours postoperatively.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT scan can be used to diagnose postoperative complications such as organ or space surgical site infection (e.g., intraabdominal abscess) and biliary leak. While an abscess can manifest with fever and abdominal pain, the tenderness is usually located in the region where surgery was performed. Moreover, surgical site infections most often occur ≥ 4 days after surgery. Biliary leak can manifest with abdominal discomfort and fever, but jaundice, nausea, and vomiting are also typically seen. Both intraabdominal abscess and biliary leak can lead to secondary bacterial peritonitis, which can manifest with signs and symptoms of sepsis; however, peritoneal signs such as rebound tenderness and/or guarding are also expected.
questions.hint: Fever, altered mental status, tachycardia, and tachypnea raise concern for postoperative sepsis. Certain postoperative measures that help to prevent sepsis may have been missed in this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 27 weeks' gestation with increased urinary frequency, a burning sensation when urinating, flank pain, and nausea. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Glucose tolerance testing performed at 25 weeks' gestation was normal. She is sexually active with her husband. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the right costovertebral area. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent with 27 weeks' gestation. Her urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites. The urine is sent for bacterial culture. Which of the following changes most likely contributed to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased levels of progesterone during pregnancy result in ureteral smooth muscle relaxation and ureteral dilation. This process begins around the 6th week of pregnancy, peaks around 22–26 weeks, and persists until delivery. The pressure exerted by the expanding uterus on the bladder also contributes to ureteral dilation. Ureteral dilation can increase urinary stasis and ureterovesical reflux, leading to higher rates of ascending bacterial infections.

The diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis should be confirmed with bacterial growth on urine culture. Treatment with intravenous empiric antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone) should be initiated and the patient should be hospitalized; antibiotics can be adjusted based on culture results if necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy results in increased metabolism, which raises the core body temperature. However, elevated body temperature is not associated with an increased risk of UTI.

C) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy increases plasma volume, which results in decreased, not increased, urine concentration. Decreased urine concentration increases the risk of UTI, as high osmolality and high urea concentrations protect against bacterial growth.

D) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy increases plasma volume, which results in increased, not decreased, urine volume. Although increased urine volume and urination can decrease the risk of UTI, high urine volumes can also promote stasis and reflux, which increase the risk of UTI.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary pH is usually slightly acidic, ranging between 4.5 and 8.0. Because urinary pH is affected by numerous factors (e.g., diet, fluid balance), it can vary greatly from day-to-day. Pregnancy is associated with increased urinary concentrations of acidic metabolites (e.g., amino acids, hormone degradation products), which decreases urinary pH. At the same time, pregnancy is associated with an increase in resting minute ventilation, causing renal excretion of bicarbonate (as a compensatory mechanism for respiratory alkalosis) and a subsequent increase in urinary pH. However, urinary pH is not known to be a strong predisposing factor for UTI.

F) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy increases, not decreases, urine glucose concentrations. During pregnancy, glycosuria is caused by increased glomerular filtration rate (resulting in more glucose entering the urine) and/or decreased reabsorptive capacity of the tubules, which increases the risk of UTI.
questions.hint: Given her symptoms and urine findings, this patient most likely has acute pyelonephritis. Hormonal changes during pregnancy affect the urinary tract, increasing the risk of asymptomatic bacteriuria and urinary tract infection (UTI), such as acute cystitis and acute pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased urinary frequency and pain on urination for two days. She has had three similar episodes over the past year that resolved with antibiotic treatment. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with one male partner; they do not use barrier contraception. Upon questioning, she reports that she always urinates and cleans herself after sexual intercourse. She drinks 2–3 liters of fluid daily. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. Examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows WBCs and rare gram-positive cocci; a urine pregnancy test is negative. Results of a urine culture are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent similar episodes in the future?

choices.text: Self-treatment at the onset of symptoms with oral cefpodoxime
Treatment of the partner with intramuscular ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Daily intake of cranberry juice is not routinely recommended for UTI prophylaxis, as the efficacy of cranberry products in preventing UTIs has not been proven and little supporting evidence exists.

B) INCORRECT:

Self-treatment of UTIs can be considered in adherent patients with recurrent UTIs to decrease the overall amount of antibiotics used. However, cefpodoxime, which is a second-line agent for acute uncomplicated cystitis in adults and a first-line agent for uncomplicated cystitis in children, is not the antibiotic agent of choice in these patients.

C) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence supporting the use of probiotics in the prevention of UTIs; therefore, they are currently not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment of the patient's partner with intramuscular ceftriaxone would be an appropriate recommendation for a patient with recurrent gonococcal infection. This patient's history of unprotected sex puts her at increased risk for sexually transmitted infections, and gonococcal infections can also cause lower abdominal pain, dysuria, and urinary frequency. However, N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative rather than a gram-positive pathogen.

E) CORRECT:

Antibiotic prophylaxis (continuous or postcoital) should be considered in all women with recurrent uncomplicated UTIs; postcoital prophylaxis is recommended if the UTIs are associated with sexual activity. A suitable regimen should be selected based on local resistance patterns, cost, and potential adverse effects. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is commonly used, but acceptable alternatives include nitrofurantoin and cephalexin. As an alternative to antibiotic prophylaxis, self-initiated antibiotic therapy at the first onset of symptoms can also be considered.

Behavioral modifications (e.g., increased fluid intake, postcoital voiding) should also be encouraged to help prevent recurrent UTIs. There is insufficient high-quality data to support the use of cranberry products or probiotics for the prevention of UTIs.
questions.hint: In combination with WBCs and gram-positive cocci (likely Staphylococcus saprophyticus) on urinalysis, urinary frequency and dysuria suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI). This patient is experiencing her fourth UTI in one year.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of severe burning pain with urination and urinary frequency. She has no history of serious illness. The patient and her husband are currently trying to conceive a child. Her only medication is a prenatal multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Examination shows mild tenderness to palpation over the suprapubic region. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8200/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Urine



 pH
7 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


 WBC

52/hpf


 RBC
17/hpf


 Protein
negative


 Nitrites

positive


 Leukocyte esterase

positive


A serum pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the bladder is indicated in patients who present with features of complicated cystitis. As this patient has no history of frequent recurrences and no features of a complicated UTI, such as pregnancy, immunocompromised status, and recent urinary tract instrumentation, a bladder ultrasound is not currently indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral ciprofloxacin is not preferred as a first-line agent for uncomplicated UTIs because of the increasing bacterial resistance to this agent. Oral ciprofloxacin is reserved as a first-line antibiotic for patients with uncomplicated pyelonephritis, which classically manifests with fever, flank pain, and/or costovertebral angle tenderness. Oral ciprofloxacin is also reserved for the treatment of complicated UTIs or as a second-line agent in uncomplicated UTIs. Because this patient has no risk factors for a complicated UTI (e.g., underlying urinary tract abnormality or immunocompromised status), and she has not received a trial of first-line therapy, oral ciprofloxacin is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up is an inappropriate next step for this patient, whose clinical presentation indicates an uncomplicated UTI. This patient requires further management because an untreated UTI can progress to complicated UTI and bacteremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin/clavulanate is not used as first-line empirical therapy for uncomplicated UTI in a woman who is not pregnant because of the increasing bacterial resistance to this antibiotic. Amoxicillin/clavulanate is reserved as a first-line empirical antibiotic for the management of acute cystitis or asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant women because it is a broad-spectrum nonteratogenic antibiotic.

E) CORRECT:

Empiric oral fosfomycin is the first-line antibiotic for uncomplicated UTI in a woman (i.e., no risk factors for complicated UTI such as pregnancy, immunocompromised status, and recent urinary tract instrumentation). Other first-line antibiotics for uncomplicated UTI are trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) and nitrofurantoin. Persistent symptoms after 2–3 days of treatment with a first-line antibiotic agent indicate possible complicated UTI and/or a need to switch to a different antibiotic regimen. Both fosfomycin and nitrofurantoin should be avoided in pyelonephritis because they are unable to reach lasting therapeutic concentrations in the upper urinary tract. Fosfomycin is also a first-line antibiotic for UTIs during pregnancy and is therefore an appropriate choice for this patient who is actively trying to conceive.

In patients with uncomplicated UTI, a urinalysis showing evidence of infection is sufficient to initiate management without a confirmatory urine culture.

F) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is the confirmatory test for UTI and is used to identify the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibility. However, urine culture is not routinely indicated to confirm an uncomplicated UTI. Common indications for urine culture include complicated UTIs, nonresponse to initial therapy of uncomplicated UTI, and dysuria or asymptomatic bacteriuria in a pregnant woman. The presence of ≥ 105 colony-forming units on urine culture (or ≥ 103 CFU/mL for symptomatic patients) confirms UTI. In patients with uncomplicated UTI, like this woman, a urinalysis confirming an infection is sufficient to initiate management.
questions.hint: This patient's dysuria alongside pyuria and a positive nitrite test on urinalysis indicate a lower urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by nitrite-producing bacteria (e.g., Enterobacteriaceae).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 1-week-history of painful urination and urinary frequency. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F). There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase. A Gram stain does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is the yeast responsible for candidal vulvovaginitis, which can also present with dysuria, as seen in this patient. However, microscopic examination would typically show branching pseudohyphae with budding yeasts, unlike the findings here. Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis typically presents with a thick cottage cheese-like vaginal discharge, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea, which can also manifest with urethritis and vulvovaginitis, as seen in this patient. However, Gram stain would typically show gram-negative diplococci, as opposed to the findings here. While gonorrhea may be asymptomatic, it often manifests with purulent, creamy vaginal discharge.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)

The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of urinary tract infections (UTI) in adults. UTI caused by E. coli can also present with dysuria, urinary frequency, and a positive leukocyte esterase test, as seen here. However, gram stain of the urine would show gram-negative rods, as opposed to the findings here.

D) INCORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram-variable rod that causes bacterial vaginosis. Sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis although it is not considered an STI. Microscopic examination would show clue cells, as opposed to this patient's findings. Moreover, bacterial vaginosis is typically painless and may present with a gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor that this patient does not have.

E) CORRECT:

This patient likely has Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Although most cases are asymptomatic, patients can present with urethritis and/or vulvovaginitis, as seen here. Chlamydiae do not gram stain well because they are obligate intracellular bacteria that lack muramic acid in their cell wall. In the diagnosis of chlamydia infection, Giemsa stain or fluorescent antibody stain can be used to identify reticulate bodies (i.e., cytoplasmic inclusions.) PCR (nucleic acid amplification) is the gold standard diagnostic test for chlamydiae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (unknown magnification)

Cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (black arrows) show inclusion bodies (reticulate bodies, here in brown) under the microscope.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular bacteria that require cell culture, rather than growth medium, to grow. This characteristic is especially important for determining the best antibiotic for treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is the causative organism of Trichomonas vaginitis, a sexually transmitted disease that typically presents with dysuria. However, microscopic examination would show motile flagellated protozoa, as opposed to the findings here. Moreover, Trichomonas vaginitis classically presents with a yellow-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.
questions.hint: This sexually active patient presents with features of urethritis and vulvovaginitis (painful urination, positive leukocyte esterase) and a negative urine Gram stain. She likely has an infection with an organism that lacks muramic acid in the cell wall.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old woman with an indwelling urinary catheter and a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis is brought to the emergency department from her nursing home because of increasing confusion over the past day. On arrival, she is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Urine studies show:


pH
8.5


WBC
40/hpf


Bacteria
moderate


Nitrites
positive


The urine has an ammonia odor. Which of the following is most likely to be present on this patient's urine culture?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive rod, is a common cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTI), due to its ability to form biofilms that are resistant to antibiotic therapy. However, it does not cause alkaline urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus saprophyticus, a gram-positive, novobiocin-resistant coccus, is a common cause of urinary tract infections in young, sexually active women. S. saprophyticus is urease-positive and has the ability to cause alkaline urine but would not explain the positive urinary nitrite test, as Staphylococcus spp. are unable to reduce nitrate.

C) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, indole-positive rod and one of the most common causes of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). However, E. coli does not cause alkaline urine, as seen in this patient. In addition, it is not typically associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis, which was mentioned in this patient's history.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, a gram-positive, gamma-hemolytic coccus, is a common cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTI). However, it does not cause alkaline urine, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, because enterococci are unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite, the urinary nitrite test would be negative.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with a urinary tract infection (UTI), alkaline urine (pH > 8), and an indwelling urinary catheter are most likely infected with Proteus mirabilis, a gram-negative, oxidase-negative rod. P. mirabilis converts urea in the urine into ammonia, which has an alkalizing effect and increases the risk of struvite stone formation. The incidence of P. mirabilis increases with the duration of catheterization and can be found in up to 40% of patients with long-term catheterization. Struvite stones often require interventional stone removal.

Klebsiella pneumonia is another common cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). While it is associated with mildly alkaline urinary pH, a urine pH levels above 8 is rare because K. pneumoniae only produces limited amounts of urease (which converts urea into ammonia).
questions.hint: This patient has a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (positive nitrites and moderate bacteria on urinalysis) with resulting delirium. The organism most likely responsible produces urease, which can convert urea into ammonia, causing elevated urinary pH. Ammonia lends the urine a characteristic scent.

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of nausea and weakness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses an oral contraceptive; she uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 4 days ago. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101°F). Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Pelvic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ascending bacteria from the endocervix can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID could explain this patient's fever, nausea, and weakness, the condition is not associated with costovertebral angle tenderness. In addition, PID would cause abdominopelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness, and possibly abnormal vaginal discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

Noninfectious inflammation of the bladder, causing chronic interstitial cystitis, manifests as a chronic pain syndrome with symptoms of urgency, increased frequency, suprapubic pain, and dyspareunia. This patient has none of these clinical features. Additionally, interstitial cystitis could not explain this patient's nausea and weakness, fever, and distinct right costovertebral angle tenderness.

C) CORRECT:

Ascending bacteria from the bladder, typically due to underlying cystitis, is the most likely cause of this patient's pyelonephritis. Other risk factors include pregnancy, urinary tract obstruction (e.g., catheter, benign prostatic hyperplasia, vesicoureteral reflux), immunosuppression, and recurrent urinary tract infections.

D) INCORRECT:

A decreased urinary pH (e.g., due to a metabolic syndrome or medication) promotes the formation of radiolucent uric acid stones. Although the patient's nausea, weakness, and right costovertebral angle tenderness can present with kidney stones, the absence of colicky flank pain that often radiates into the groin area makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Since ∼ ⅔ of calcium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, a decrease in renal calcium reabsorption can cause radioopaque calcium urinary stones to form. Renal stones would be most common in individuals with excessive supplemental calcium intake or taking certain medications, such as loop diuretics or topiramate. Although the patient's nausea, weakness, and right costovertebral angle tenderness can present with kidney stones, the absence of colicky flank pain that often radiates into the groin area makes this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: Costovertebral angle tenderness, nausea, and fever are classic characteristics of pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency room because of a 3-day history of fever and shaking chills. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination of the back shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Analysis of the urine shows WBCs, WBC casts, and gram-negative rods. Ultrasound examination of the kidneys shows no signs of obstruction. Biopsy of the patient's kidney is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrates
Widespread granulomatous tissue and foamy macrophages
Cystic dilation of the renal medulla

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate are pathognomonic for clear cell renal cell carcinoma. Patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma typically present with hematuria, flank pain, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss) that develop over many months. This patient's presentation is very acute (only 3 days) and features a high fever, neither of which could be explained by this neoplastic process.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Countless nests of polygonal cells (examples indicated by green overlays) with clear cytoplasm, filled with lipids and glycogen, are visible (examples indicated by yellow overlays). The tissue is richly vascularized (examples of blood vessels indicated by arrowheads).

This is the typical histopathological appearance of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

B) CORRECT:

Polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) in the tubules are the classic biopsy finding in bacterial infections. The bacteria attach to the tubular epithelium and trigger an inflammatory response. As a result, pro-inflammatory chemokines (e.g., IL-8) are released and the epithelium becomes permeable. This allows PMNs to enter the tubules and fight the infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a renal tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain, very high magnification)

Areas of neutrophilic infiltration are visible throughout the renal interstitium (example indicated by hatched green overlay), especially in the tubules (example indicated by green overlay), which appear dilated.

These findings suggest acute pyelonephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Widespread granulomatous tissue and foamy macrophages are seen in xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis, if symptomatic, would be seen on ultrasound examination as an enlarged kidney with hypoechoic masses. This patient's imaging is unremarkable, which excludes this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystic dilation of the renal medulla is seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Patients with ADPKD usually present at a younger age with recurrent flank and/or abdominal pain, recurrent episodes of UTIs, and bilateral renal masses palpable on exam. Self-limited hematuria is also a very common manifestation. Ultrasound examination demonstrates the presence of numerous cysts; this patient, however, has an unremarkable ultrasound, no renal masses on examination, and a history inconsistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Sloughing of necrotic renal papillae is seen in cases of renal papillary necrosis. Clinically, this often presents as gross, painless hematuria. Affected patients will classically have a history of sickle cell disease, chronic NSAID use, or acute pyelonephritis. Although this patient is suffering from acute pyelonephritis, red cells are not seen on urinalysis and the patient is not reporting hematuria. While this finding could possibly be observed, it is not the most likely finding.

F) INCORRECT:

Tubular eosinophilic casts (i.e., casts that stain with eosin, not casts made up of eosinophil remnants) are seen in chronic pyelonephritis. The biopsy findings can resemble thyroid tissue. Recurrent infections, typically associated with an underlying predisposition, such as an obstruction or vesicoureteral reflux, are a hallmark of the history. This patient's presentation, however, is consistent with acute pyelonephritis.
questions.hint: The patient's high fever, chills, costovertebral angle tenderness, and findings of pyuria and bacteriuria are consistent with acute pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is scheduled to be transferred to a neurologic rehabilitation center after hospitalization and surgery for multiple vertebral fractures sustained in a motor vehicle collision 3 weeks ago. She was discharged from the intensive care unit on postoperative day 5 with an indwelling transurethral catheter. A trial to remove the catheter led to an episode of urinary retention, and indwelling catheter therapy was ordered for the remainder of the hospital stay. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows slightly decreased strength and muscle tone with full range of motion of her upper extremities and flaccid paralysis of her lower extremities. Rectal tone is decreased. The physician concludes that the patient requires a longer period of catheterization for bladder control. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to reduce the risk of urinary tract infection in this patient?

choices.text: Suprapubic catheterization and regular bladder irrigation
Indwelling transurethral catheterization and use of antibacterial lubricants
Clean intermittent catheterization and routine hand hygiene measures
Suprapubic catheterization and prophylactic oral antibiotic therapy
Indwelling transurethral catheterization and periodic catheter changes
Clean intermittent catheterization and regular screening for bacteriuria

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Suprapubic catheterization has some advantages over other catheterization methods (e.g., greater patient satisfaction, prevention of urethral strictures and trauma). However, it may be associated with a higher risk of urinary tract infection compared to a more appropriate method of bladder management. Additionally, regular bladder irrigation has not been shown to prevent CAUTIs and may actually increase the risk of infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Although indwelling transurethral catheters should be used initially for bladder emptying in patients with SCI, they should be replaced by a different catheterization method after 3–4 days to reduce the risk of CAUTIs. Additionally, the use of antibacterial lubricants has not been shown to prevent CAUTIs and may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

C) CORRECT:

While patients with spinal cord injury initially require an indwelling urinary catheter in order to prevent bladder distension due to urine retention, the indwelling catheter should be removed after 3–4 days and substituted with clean intermittent catheterization (CIC). CIC consists of the insertion and removal of a urinary catheter directly after emptying the bladder and needs to be performed at regular intervals (4–6 times a day). CIC can be used in short- and long-term settings and performed by a caregiver or the patient. This technique is associated with fewer CAUTIs than indwelling catheters, prevents complications (e.g., sepsis), and reduces mortality. Routine hand hygiene is crucial and should always be performed before and after CIC to reduce the risk of pathogen transmission.

D) INCORRECT:

Suprapubic catheterization has some advantages over other catheterization methods (e.g., greater patient satisfaction, prevention of urethral strictures and trauma). However, it may be associated with a higher risk of urinary tract infection compared to a more appropriate method of bladder management. Additionally, oral antimicrobial prophylaxis has not been shown to prevent CAUTIs and may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with SCI, indwelling transurethral catheters are used initially for bladder emptying and should be replaced by a different catheterization method after 3–4 days to reduce the risk of CAUTIs. Additionally, periodic changes of an indwelling transurethral catheter have not been shown to prevent CAUTIs. In general, these catheters should only be changed if there is a mechanical issue (e.g., clogging) and a continued need for indwelling catheterization.

F) INCORRECT:

Clean intermittent catheterization is associated with a decreased risk of CAUTIs. However, screening for bacteriuria has not been shown to prevent these infections and is, therefore, not recommended.
questions.hint: The long-term goals in the management of neurogenic lower urinary tract dysfunction due to spinal cord injury (SCI) are maintaining renal function and allowing individuals to void completely, regularly, and at convenient times while avoiding complications, such as catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs).

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 14 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 7 days after completing a course of cefpodoxime for asymptomatic bacteriuria with Escherichia coli. She has not had dysuria, hematuria, or changes in urinary frequency. Fetal ultrasonography performed during her last prenatal visit at 12 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. One year ago, she was treated with metronidazole for trichomoniasis. Her only medications are folic acid and vitamin C. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No further management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy is associated with maternal complications (e.g., pyelonephritis, preeclampsia) and fetal complications (e.g., low birth weight, perinatal mortality due to preterm birth), and thus should always be managed with antibiotic therapy. Since up to one-third of patients have persistent bacteriuria after initial antibiotic therapy, all patients require a follow-up urine culture around one week after treatment to guide further management. Patients with a negative follow-up urine culture require no further testing for bacteriuria unless UTI symptoms develop. Women with persistent bacteriuria should receive another course of antibiotic therapy based on the follow-up culture results.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis should be obtained in pregnant women who present with symptoms of a UTI (e.g., dysuria, urinary urgency, urinary frequency). Although urinalysis offers extensive information on blood cells and microbes in the urine, it is not necessary for the follow-up evaluation of patients who had asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal and pelvic ultrasonography is used to screen for complications of pyelonephritis (e.g., perinephric abscess, emphysematous pyelonephritis). Although this patient's asymptomatic bacteriuria puts her at increased risk of developing pyelonephritis, she does not have any features that suggest upper urinary tract involvement (e.g., flank pain, fever, chills). Ultrasonography is not necessary for the follow-up evaluation of patients who have asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic nitrofurantoin is indicated for pregnant women with recurrent UTIs (e.g., recurrent cystitis and/or pyelonephritis). This patient, however, has no prior history of UTI during pregnancy. Prophylactic nitrofurantoin is not indicated in patients with asymptomatic bacteriuria, even if it is persistent or recurrent.

E) INCORRECT:

No further management is indicated in pregnant patients with asymptomatic bacteriuria who respond to antibiotic therapy. Although this patient has completed a 7-day course of cefpodoxime, it is unknown whether this treatment has resolved her asymptomatic bacteriuria. For this reason, a different step is required at this time.
questions.hint: Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy increases the risk of maternal urinary tract infections (UTIs) such as pyelonephritis, which can lead to maternal and fetal complications.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports having dysuria, increased urinary urgency, and suprapubic discomfort for the past 3 days. She states that she does not have any fever, nausea, vomiting, or flank pain. She had similar symptoms 2 months ago, at which time she was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
Urinalysis shows 2+ leukocyte esterase and is positive for nitrite. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The patient has no known medication allergies.
Which one of the following antibiotics is the best choice for empiric treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute uncomplicated cystitis typically manifests with dysuria, increased urinary urgency, or suprapubic discomfort in the absence of systemic symptoms such as fever or flank pain. When choosing an appropriate antibiotic for empiric treatment of this condition in an otherwise healthy woman, one should avoid agents with broad-spectrum activity because they can lead to the selection of drug-resistant organisms. Nitrofurantoin has been shown both to be efficacious and to have minimal propensity for selecting drug-resistant organisms; therefore, it is considered the first-line option in an otherwise healthy patient.

Key learning point: The best choice for empiric antibiotic treatment of uncomplicated cystitis in a woman who received trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole in the past 3 months is nitrofurantoin.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an appropriate choice for empiric treatment if the local prevalence of drug resistance in uropathogens does not exceed 20% or if there is no use of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole in the preceding 3 months. Prior use is an independent risk factor for trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole resistance in women with acute uncomplicated cystitis. Fosfomycin would be another reasonable empiric treatment in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin and other beta-lactam agents generally have inferior efficacy and higher relapse rates than other first-line antibiotics used in treating urinary tract infections; one potential explanation is that penicillins and cephalosporins also are active against lactobacilli, which are an important component of normal vaginal flora. The elimination of lactobacillus allows proliferation of potential gram-negative uropathogens, such as Escherichia coli.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin should not be used for empiric treatment, given the high prevalence of antibiotic resistance worldwide.

E) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones are highly efficacious for treating acute cystitis, but their use can promote fluoroquinolone resistance. These broad-spectrum antibiotics should be reserved for treatment when other first-line antibiotics are not suitable.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman with a history of frequent urinary tract infections, who has a chronic suprapubic catheter to manage a neurogenic bladder associated with multiple sclerosis, presents for follow-up. A urine culture, obtained 3 days earlier, documented >100,000 colony-forming units/mL of pan-sensitive Escherichia coli.
The patient denies fevers, dysuria, suprapubic discomfort, flank pain, or any other symptoms. The suprapubic catheter was replaced within the past month.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria, which occurs in virtually all patients with chronic indwelling urinary catheters, does not require treatment even if an accompanying urinalysis documents pyuria. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is also not recommended.

Although bacteriuria increases the risk for symptomatic urinary infections, treating asymptomatic bacteriuria does not limit the frequency of future symptomatic infections or improve other outcomes.

B) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria, which occurs in virtually all patients with chronic indwelling urinary catheters, does not require treatment even if an accompanying urinalysis documents pyuria. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is also not recommended.

Although bacteriuria increases the risk for symptomatic urinary infections, treating asymptomatic bacteriuria does not limit the frequency of future symptomatic infections or improve other outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria, which occurs in virtually all patients with chronic indwelling urinary catheters, does not require treatment even if an accompanying urinalysis documents pyuria. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is also not recommended.

Although bacteriuria increases the risk for symptomatic urinary infections, treating asymptomatic bacteriuria does not limit the frequency of future symptomatic infections or improve other outcomes.

D) CORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria, which occurs in virtually all patients with chronic indwelling urinary catheters, does not require treatment even if an accompanying urinalysis documents pyuria. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is also not recommended.

Although bacteriuria increases the risk for symptomatic urinary infections, treating asymptomatic bacteriuria does not limit the frequency of future symptomatic infections or improve other outcomes.

The only groups who benefit from screening and treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria are pregnant women and patients who undergo traumatic urologic interventions that result in mucosal bleeding.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for an asymptomatic patient with a chronic indwelling urinary catheter who has a urine culture showing >100,000 colony-forming units/mL of pan-sensitive Escherichia coli is no treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria, which occurs in virtually all patients with chronic indwelling urinary catheters, does not require treatment even if an accompanying urinalysis documents pyuria. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is also not recommended.

Although bacteriuria increases the risk for symptomatic urinary infections, treating asymptomatic bacteriuria does not limit the frequency of future symptomatic infections or improve other outcomes.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man with dementia is evaluated for an abnormal urinalysis. He has a chronic indwelling urinary catheter to help manage incontinence in the setting of chronic bladder outlet obstruction. He does not have diabetes mellitus or other immunocompromising conditions. He says he does not experience urinary urgency or other urinary symptoms. He is afebrile and has no suprapubic or costovertebral angle tenderness.
His urinalysis shows 1+ leukocyte esterase, negative nitrates, 5 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), and 3 red cells per high-power field (0–2). His urine culture grows 100,000 colony-forming units/mL of Candida albicans.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Perform bladder irrigation with amphotericin B

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Asymptomatic candiduria is common, especially in patients with a urinary catheter, and usually represents colonization. Differentiating between colonization and infection can be challenging, especially in the setting of a catheter, which can itself cause pyuria.

In patients who are asymptomatic and do not have known risk factors for fungus ball formation (such as diabetes mellitus and certain urologic abnormalities), replacing the catheter and repeating the urine culture is often sufficient. Antifungal therapy is generally not required. In these patients, oral fluconazole and bladder irrigation with amphotericin B generally result in only short-term resolution of the candiduria, with rapid recurrence and potential for selection of resistant Candida. Neither treatment has been shown to result in eradication or to improve long-term outcomes in asymptomatic patients who do not have risk factors for more complicated infections.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management of asymptomatic urinary catheter-associated candiduria is to change the catheter. Antifungal therapy is generally not required.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients who are asymptomatic and do not have known risk factors for fungus ball formation, antifungal therapy is generally not required. In these patients, oral fluconazole generally results in only short-term resolution of the candiduria, with rapid recurrence and potential for selection of resistant Candida.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic patients and those with persistent candiduria who have risk factors for fungus ball formation warrant further investigation with renal ultrasound or abdominal CT to assess for renal involvement. In patients requiring treatment, oral fluconazole has excellent bioavailability, so intravenous administration is needed only in those who are unable to swallow or absorb pills.

D) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is usually susceptible to fluconazole; therefore, even when antifungal treatment is indicated, micafungin and other echinocandin antifungals are not appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients who are asymptomatic and do not have known risk factors for fungus ball formation, oral fluconazole and bladder irrigation with amphotericin B generally result in only short-term resolution of the candiduria, with rapid recurrence and potential for selection of resistant Candida. Neither treatment has been shown to result in eradication or to improve long-term outcomes in asymptomatic patients who do not have risk factors for more-complicated infections.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old sexually active woman reports urinary urgency, frequency, and dysuria for the past 2 days. She has had no fevers, chills, flank pain, nausea, or vomiting. She has a history of recurrent, uncomplicated urinary tract infections, and this episode is her third in the past year. Three months ago, a symptomatic episode resolved after 3 days of treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She received fosfomycin for another urinary tract infection 6 months ago.
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg, her heart rate is 65 beats per minute, and her temperature is 36.5°C. She has mild tenderness on palpation of the suprapubic area in the midline, but no flank or costovertebral-area tenderness on either side. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
Urinalysis reveals 50 to 100 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and positive findings for nitrite and for leukocyte esterase.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Amoxicillin 500 mg 3 times daily for 3 days
Nitrofurantoin 100 mg twice daily for 5 days
Ciprofloxacin 250 mg twice daily for 3 days
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160 mg/800 mg twice daily for 10 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is no longer a first-line drug for uncomplicated cystitis because of a high prevalence of resistance to it.

B) CORRECT:

For a woman with a recurrent, uncomplicated lower urinary tract infection (cystitis) who was recently treated with courses of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin, another first-line agent should be chosen; in this setting, nitrofurantoin is an appropriate choice, as it has >90% efficacy and minimal adverse effects. Nitrofurantoin should not be used in patients with pyelonephritis or patients with kidney impairment (as evidenced by an estimated glomerular filtration rate <60 mL/min/1.73 m2). A 5-day course of nitrofurantoin (not single-dose therapy) is the standard regimen. A rare but serious adverse effect is an acute pulmonary hypersensitivity reaction.

Obtaining a urine culture before treatment is probably unnecessary in this patient, whose cystitis episodes are separated by at least several months. However, if she fails to respond to this course of antibiotic or has a relapse within several weeks, obtaining a culture would be appropriate.

Key learning point: In a woman presenting with a recurrence of acute simple cystitis, a different first-line antibiotic than was used for the initial episode should be chosen if the initial episode was within the past 3 to 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration recommends against the use of ciprofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones for treatment of uncomplicated cystitis unless there are no other treatment options. This recommendation is based on the fact that the risks of serious side effects from fluoroquinolones generally outweigh their benefits in this setting. In contrast, ciprofloxacin is still recommended for oral therapy in uncomplicated pyelonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

For a woman with a recurrent, uncomplicated lower urinary tract infection (cystitis) who was recently treated with courses of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin, another first-line agent should be chosen; in this setting, nitrofurantoin is an appropriate choice, as it has >90% efficacy and minimal adverse effects. A 5-day course of nitrofurantoin (not single-dose therapy) is the standard regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Use of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole within the past 3 to 6 months places a patient at above-average risk for developing bacterial isolates that are resistant to this antibiotic, so retreatment with this drug is not optimal. Furthermore, when trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used for uncomplicated cystitis, a 3-day course (not a 10-day course) is usually adequate.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of dysuria that is worse toward the end of urination. She also reports increased urinary frequency and an occasional pinkish discoloration in the toilet-bowl water. She states that she does not experience fever, chills, or diarrhea. Her medical history is notable for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Four months ago, she traveled to East Africa for a kayaking trip, where she experienced flulike symptoms that lasted approximately 2 weeks. A urine dipstick test is positive for blood; urine culture is negative for bacterial growth.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Microscopic examination of three separate samples of urine on different days
Stool testing for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dysuria in a middle-aged woman usually suggests uncomplicated cystitis; however, this patient was exposed to fresh water in an area endemic to Schistosoma haematobium, raising the likelihood of this infection.

Schistosoma haematobium infestation occurs when cercariae penetrate the skin. During the acute phase, flulike symptoms may occur; this syndrome is known as Katayama fever. Mature worms lay ova in the perivesical venous plexi; the ova can penetrate the bladder lining. Depending on the worm and ova burden, patients can be asymptomatic or have dysuria and hematuria, both of which are typically worse at the end of urination, when the bladder contracts maximally. The diagnosis is made by microscopy and by identifying the characteristic ova in the urine.

Schistosoma shed more ova midday, so a noon-time specimen collection is ideal. Three urine samples should be collected on different days to increase the sensitivity of testing. The treatment is typically a single dose of praziquantel timed at least 8 weeks after the last exposure to potentially contaminated fresh water.

Serologic testing for schistosomiasis is also an option when considering this diagnosis. Of note, the tests generally take 6 to 12 weeks to turn positive (so they may be negative during acute infection), and a positive serologic test does not indicate the site of infection. In this case, it would be reasonable to send serologic testing as an adjunct to the urine microscopy.

Key learning point: In a patient exposed to fresh water in tropical or subtropical Africa, an infectious cause of dysuria and hematuria is Schistosoma haematobium.

B) INCORRECT:
